U.S. Deprioritizes International Environmental Pacts: Implications for Higher Education

Overview: This executive order signals a major shift in U.S. environmental policy, subordinating international agreements to domestic priorities. While framed as protecting American jobs, it could undermine climate research funding, increase campus sustainability costs, and strain global research partnerships. Universities must carefully assess the myriad potential impacts.

Bottom Line: This order could fundamentally reshape how universities approach sustainability research, education, and practice. Proactive planning is needed to adapt to new funding and policy realities.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

This continues a pattern of environmental deregulation under the current administration, but takes a more aggressive stance toward international agreements. It cites the need to protect U.S. economic interests and questions climate science.

Legal Framework:

While the President has broad foreign policy powers, there are legal questions about unilaterally withdrawing from ratified agreements. Implementation may require Congressional action. Prior court rulings on Clean Air Act and other laws could constrain EPA.

Higher Education Context:

Fossil fuel companies strongly support the order; clean energy/tech firms oppose it. This reflects a growing partisan divide in higher ed, with GOP questioning liberal bias and Dems defending academic freedom. Comes amid increased public scrutiny of university finances.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Sponsored Research: Major cuts likely for projects related to climate change, energy transition, and other areas tied to international agreements. May affect federal agencies like NSF, DOE, EPA and others.

Campus Sustainability: U.S. withdrawal from agreements like Paris Accord could increase university energy/emissions costs and complicate progress toward institutional sustainability goals.

Global Engagement: Damaged relationships with international partners and reduced ability to contribute to or shape global environmental and climate efforts. Could reduce appeal to international students and scholars.

Education and Outreach: Politicization of climate issues could affect grant funding for environmental education, community outreach, and related programs. May require new approaches.

Facilities and Capital Planning: Changing federal policies and incentives could disrupt plans for renewable energy, carbon reduction, and other sustainability projects. May require financing and design changes.

Important Dates:

  • 03/15/2025: Deadline for agencies to submit plans for implementing the order
  • 07/01/2025: New rules to prioritize U.S. interests take effect
  • 10/01/2025: Withdrawal process from unspecified international environmental agreements begins
  • 01/01/2026: Changes to enforcement of domestic emissions and energy standards take effect

Affected Departments:

President/Chancellor's Office, Research Administration, Government Affairs, Facilities Management, EHS & Sustainability, Finance/Budget Office, Communications, International Programs, Advancement/Foundation Relations, Specific Academic Departments

Implementation Details:

Compliance Requirements:

Detailed agency guidance is still pending, but institutions will likely need to document 'American first' approach to environmental research, including justifications for any international collaborations. May require review of export controls.

Technical Analysis:

The new requirements could complicate compliance with NSF and other agency standards for research conduct. IT systems may require updates to track domestic vs. international environmental components separately.

Cross-Functional Impacts:

Research, facilities, finance, and communications teams will need to work closely to balance compliance, budget, and reputational considerations. Academic departments may need to modify curricula and student engagement.

Risk Analysis:

Failure to comply with contracting and spending rules could bring audit risks. Insufficient action could damage reputation with domestic and global stakeholders. Overreaction could unnecessarily curtail valid programs.

Strategic Considerations:

Competitive Implications:

Research-intensive institutions will likely see the greatest impact. Those in fossil fuel-dependent regions could benefit from relaxed regulations. Schools with strong environmental brands may attract more students and funding.

Long-term Vision:

U.S. environmental retrenchment could accelerate global leadership shifts in environmental domains. Universities may play a balancing role by maintaining some international engagement and scientific collaboration.

Advocacy Opportunities:

Universities can argue that sound environmental research and policies support U.S. economic competitiveness. Emphasis on research integrity and institutional autonomy may resonate in Congress.

Action Plan:

Action Required: Yes - This order could have severe and long-lasting impacts across multiple areas. Universities must act quickly to assess vulnerabilities, realign strategies, and engage policymakers. But some effects may be beyond institutional control.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Brief senior leadership and trustees; form cross-functional working group to coordinate response
  • Map affected research portfolio and partnerships; quantify potential losses
  • Identify global MOUs/contracts with environmental requirements; assess liability
  • Evaluate impact on emissions reduction and renewable energy commitments/plans

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Mobilize government affairs staff to engage Congressional representatives and agency contacts
  • Develop communications plan to manage stakeholder questions and concerns
  • Initiate budget planning to absorb anticipated revenue losses and increased costs
  • Identify alternative funding sources and partnership structures for affected areas

Long-term Considerations:

  • Join associations and peer institutions to advocate for research funding and environmental policies
  • Incorporate new budget and policy realities into next strategic planning cycle
  • Monitor changes in student/employee attitudes toward institutional environmental stance

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: Will need to dedicate a team to track developments, engage government, and coordinate internal response. Many offices will face increased workload to implement changes. Specific expertise in energy/environmental law and accounting may be needed.

Budget: Institutions should scenario plan for a range of funding losses and compliance costs over several years. Contingency funds, reserves, and alternative revenue sources may need to be deployed. Consider impacts on debt and financing.

Technology: Enhanced reporting systems may be required to demonstrate compliance. Some institutions may need to upgrade energy monitoring and management tools. Consider cybersecurity needs for politically sensitive information.

External Expertise: Consider engaging lobbying firms, legal counsel, and communications consultants to support advocacy, compliance, and stakeholder engagement. External advisory boards may provide valuable strategic guidance.
